original_title: Brooklyn: Brighton Beach Avenue - Mayo Street
text:
(1) Brighton Beach Ave., north side, east of Mayo Street, showing a former Long Island R.R. station at Manhattan Beach, which ceased to be used as such, prior to 1929. This railroad was built by Austin Corbin in 1876-1877 and operated from the foot of West End Ave., Manhattan Beach, to Baldwin's Hotel in East New York. It was later extended to the foot of Quay Street, Greenpoint, and connected with New York at the 10th and 23rd Street ferries. Trains ran there first on April 9, 1878, but were diverted to Hunter's Point, a branch line built from Prospect Park in 1878. In 1880, the trains ran directly from Atlantic Ave. Station.

December 1923.

Eugene L. Armbruster.

(2) The same, showing the platform fallen in decay. Note also an abandoned freight car between the two buildings. At the left is seen the Manhattan Beach Hotel at Nos. 156-158 West End Ave., and also Nos. 5961-5963 Brighton Beach Ave.

December 1923.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(3) The same, looking southward.

December 1923.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(4) The same, looking north.

December 1923.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
